Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: At home, the child is learning daily manners, and the parent should provide guidance
Expectation2: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation2: One aircraft is about to cross into the neighboring sector on a normal route.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, watching my son fidget with his spoon, milk dripping onto the floor. “Remember, we keep our place tidy,” I reminded him gently, trying to teach him the importance of discipline. He looked up at me, eyes wide, waiting for my guidance. Just then, my headset crackled—my shift as an air traffic controller had started early today, and I was monitoring the radar from home. A blip appeared: Flight 237 was approaching the sector boundary, and I needed to coordinate with the next controller to ensure a smooth handoff. My son’s gaze pulled at me, expecting my full attention and patience as he struggled to clean up his mess. At the same time, my screen demanded my focus, the expectation clear: keep the skies safe, communicate quickly, don’t let anything slip. My heart pounded as I tried to split myself between the two worlds, feeling the weight of both responsibilities pressing in, each one urgent, each one needing me right now.
